results.name: David Dalaithngu
results.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

key_work.title: Spotlights: David Dalaithngu
key_work.brief_description: A Yolŋu traditional dancer and actor who changed the way the Australian screen represents First Peoples and their cultural heritage. He reached the pinnacle of success in the 1970s with roles in a string of award-winning films including Walkabout (1971) and Storm Boy (1976).

constellations_primary.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_primary.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

start.title: Sweet Country
start.creator_credit: Warwick Thornton, Heather Wallace, David Jowsey, Greer Simpkin, Bunya Productions, Tony Cronin, David Tranter and Steven McGregor
start.brief_description: It’s 1929 on the vast, desert-like, Eastern Arrernte Nation lands that are now known as the Central Australian outback. Sam Kelly, a middle-aged Aboriginal man, works the land of a kind preacher, Fred Smith. After an ill-tempered bully arrives in town and Kelly kills him in self-defence, he and his wife go on the run as a posse gathers to hunt him down.

constellations_primary.name: Sweet Country
constellations_primary.description: Warwick Thornton’s feature film Sweet Country is based on the story of Wilaberta Jack, which was told to sound recordist David Tranter by his grandfather and translated into storyboards.

constellations_other.name: The Australian industry
constellations_other.description: Though our local industry is small, our impact is huge.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Fred Schepisi
constellations_other.description: Fred Schepisi's diverse body of work connects to acclaimed local productions, westerns and Hollywood favourites.

constellations_other.name: Native Tongue
constellations_other.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

constellations_other.name: Outlawed
constellations_other.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Inspired design and costume sketches
constellations_other.description: Costume designers Edie Kurzer and Alice Babidge have worked on some of the most acclaimed Australian and international films and TV, joining the ranks of fellow Australians creatives.

links.description: Jennifer Kent’s follow-up to the critically acclaimed The Babadook, follows an Irish immigrant and Indigenous teen who track down racist colonial police in a brutal revenge drama that resists the dominant narratives of colonialism.

end.title: Walkabout
end.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Si Litvinoff and Max L. Raab - Si Litvinoff Films
end.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister and her young brother left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They’re rescued by a young Aboriginal man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood.

links.description: Legendary Yolngu actor and dancer David Dalaithngu has a career spanning five decades. His first role was in Nicholas Roeg’s Walkabout, where he starred as a First Nations teen leading stranded white children to safety in the Outback.

links.description: Five years after wowing audiences with his performance in Walkabout, Dalaithngu starred in the beloved Australian film Stormboy, where he once again serves as a friend and mentor to a young boy and helps him navigate life.

end.title: Ten Canoes
end.creator_credit: Julie Ryan, Rolf de Heer, Fandango and Vertigo Productions
end.brief_description: Filmed in Arnhem Land with a cast of local Indigenous Australians, Ten Canoes interweaves two tales of forbidden love and consequence, spanning thousands of years of Yolngu storytelling, and is told entirely in language.

links.description: Dalaithngu reportedly learned English while making his first film, adding the language to the list of Indigenous languages he already spoke. Thirty five years after learning English, he narrated Ten Canoes, which is otherwise entirely in the Yolŋu Matha language.

links.description: Popular social media site Reddit banned their channel r/thedonald, one of the key channels supporting Trump and the alt-right movement. The subreddit was banned for promoting hate-speech. This foreshadowed Trump himself being banned from Twitter and Facebook in early 2021 for inciting violence.

links.description: Speeches like these from Donald Trump, before right-wing insurgents stormed the Capitol building in Washington DC, demonstrate the threat of wilfully dismissing the truth. Despite there being no evidence that Joe Biden wasn’t fairly elected, #stopthesteal swept across social media and inspired protests.

end.title: Trump supporters minding the velvet ropes
end.creator_credit: C-Span
end.material_description: Digital screen recording from C-Span's YouTube channel
end.brief_description: After years of consuming viral misinformation, pro-Trump insurgents stormed the US Capitol building in early 2021, pausing their vandalising and looting only to take selfies, as if part of a legitimate sightseeing tour. They even obeyed the velvet ropes, despite dismissing democracy.

constellations_other.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_other.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

links.description: After Donald Trump incited the mob to riot through the Capitol building, they did just that. Despite the criminal activity they were undertaking, they adhered to keeping within the velvet guide ropes (at least initially) as if they were on a legitimate tour of the building.

constellations_other.name: Fake news: too little too late
constellations_other.description: Unbound Creations’ Headliner: NoviNews explores the impact of the media and fake news on society, something that is fast becoming one of the biggest concerns of our age.

links.description: After Trump was banned from Twitter and Facebook for inciting violence, many alt-right supporters (including white supremacist group The Proud Boys) began using an alternative app called Parler. Google and Apple suspended the app from their stores in early 2021 for also inciting violence.

results.name: Black Power through film and TV
results.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

key_work.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley
key_work.brief_description: Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor, Professor Gary Foley charts the intersection of Indigenous activism and the world of film and TV in this short film by Yaegl director, producer and storyteller Pauline Clague.

constellations_primary.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_primary.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

start.title: Black Fire (Blackfire)
start.brief_description: Blackfire is one of the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. It is a collection of connected ideas and a take on both the state of Anthropology and Aboriginal Affairs in 1972.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

end.title: Backroads
end.creator_credit: Phil Noyce and Backroads Productions
end.brief_description: The story of two men on the run from the police in outback NSW, Backroads was the first feature film in which First Peoples made a major creative contribution, other than fine acting.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights released films on Black Australia to mixed success but Backroads, made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.creator_credit: Richard Lowenstein, Jill Bilcock, Glenys Rowe, Burrowes Film Group and Entertainment Media
end.brief_description: Young people enjoy the summer of 1979 in the belief that they will never grow up and join the adult world. Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space, playing the character Barry, who was based on him.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

links.description: Also in the 1980s, Gary Foley appeared in the family favourite TV show A Country Practice. This pop culture moment, although brief, arguably reached a much wider audience than protests and demonstrate the power of screen culture as a tool of activism.

start.title: Basically Black
start.creator_credit: ABC
start.brief_description: Basically Black combined comedy, activism and performing arts while reflecting the political struggles and organising of 1960s and 70s Redfern. The first TV program written and performed by an all-Indigenous cast, this groundbreaking program tackled racism and white paternalism through humour.

constellations_primary.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_primary.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

end.title: Black Comedy
end.creator_credit: Scarlett Pictures
end.brief_description: Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go. Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers, including many special cameo appearances.

constellations_other.name: Expansive light in science fiction and fantasy
constellations_other.description: Visual artists have identified the importance of light in revealing the expansiveness of our universe. Explore how artists’ perception of light has been adapted and referenced in science fiction and fantasy on screen.

constellations_other.name: Little, big worlds
constellations_other.description: Wes Anderson's stop-motion animation film draws on tried-and-true techniques that, despite the rise of computer-generated imagery, still inspire filmmakers and game-makers.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

constellations_other.name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design
constellations_other.description: In No Code’s sci-fi thriller players take command of a multi-national space station’s artificial intelligence system to help the sole survivor solve the mystery of a missing crew and why the station is wildly off course.

constellations_other.name: The Kubrick connection
constellations_other.description: The visual effects for Blade Runner drew on a number of techniques from other iconic films, including two of Stanley Kubrick's masterpieces.

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

links.description: One of the godfather’s of sci-fi tropes is Ridley Scott’s Blade Runner, which helped establish the look and feel of a smog-choked, neon-lit near future. It also features machines that have grown sentient like algorithms might one day….

end.brief_description: In the early 1990s, Nintendo didn’t allow sex, drugs and alcohol to appear on its consoles. Games also couldn’t show blood or graphic violence. This presented a challenge for Australian developers Beam Software, who were turning the gritty pen-and-paper roleplaying game Shadowrun into a future classic.

constellations_other.description: Many screen-based narratives focus on packing up and moving house, new starts and teenage bedrooms, or are entirely shot in one room, revealing what we can learn about characters from a domestic environment.

links.description: HBO’s teen drama Euphoria could never be accused of featuring the types of perfect, athletic white teens that soaps from the past like Beverly HIlls: 90210 or The OC celebrated, with a cast that reflects society’s diverse racial and gender identities, sexualities and body types.

results.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
results.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million YouTube views. It's tongue-in-cheek approach to reflects a unique way of advertising that cuts through and make an impact, like the other ads featured in this Constellation.

key_work.title: How to Sell to Australia
key_work.brief_description: Since the beginning of television, Australian advertising has embedded itself into the national psyche through harnessing the moving image. Advertisers haven’t just sold products to Australian audiences, they’ve also built community, spread iconic catchphrases and created beloved characters.

constellations_primary.name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising
constellations_primary.description: The MTA’s "Dumb Ways to Die" has over 300 million YouTube views. It's tongue-in-cheek approach to reflects a unique way of advertising that cuts through and make an impact, like the other ads featured in this Constellation.

start.title: Anti-tobacco advertising
start.brief_description: In 1968, a cigarette ad ran every 14 minutes on Australian TV. Cancer Council Victoria director Nigel Gray responded with a star-studded anti-tobacco campaign launched in 1971, which became the foundation for boundary-pushing anti-smoking filmmaking in Australia. These ads became part of our collective consciousness and their messages continue to inspire people to quit.

results.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
results.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

key_work.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
key_work.material_description: Video loop, artist and Michael Bonner (performer)
key_work.brief_description: Shadow play, projection and performance combine to question our history and shift the colonial gaze in Ali Gumillya Baker’s mixed media video installation.

end.title: E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial
end.creator_credit: Steven Spielberg, Kathleen Kennedy, Amblin Entertainment, Universal Pictures, James D. Bissell, Melissa Mathison, Al Bailey and Carlo Rambaldi
end.brief_description: After a gentle alien becomes stranded on Earth, the being is discovered and befriended by a young boy named Elliott. Bringing the extraterrestrial into his suburban California house, Elliott introduces E.T., as the alien is dubbed, to his brother and his little sister, Gertie, and the children decide to keep its existence a secret. Soon, however, E.T. falls ill, resulting in government intervention and a dire situation for both Elliott and the alien.

end.title: The Lion king
end.creator_credit: Rob Minkoff, Roger Allers, Don Hahn and Walt Disney Pictures
end.brief_description: This beautifully animated and wonderfully scored feature film tells the story of the love between a proud lion ruler, Mufasa, and his son, Simba - a naive and curious cub who must find his place in the “circle of life”. Through the help of his friends, and his determination to meet the toughest challenges, Simba eventually takes his place as the rightful ruler of the Pride Lands. His search to meet his destiny puts him face to face in a struggle to the death with his evil uncle Scar and also leads him towards true love. Elton John and Tim Rice’s award winning songs, an excellent score by Hans Zimmer, and voice characterisations by Jeremy Irons, James Earl Jones, Rowan Atkinson, Robert Guillame, Moira Kelly and Matthew Broderick as Simba, make this an unforgettable experience.

links.description: Her films are known for breathtaking visual storytelling with characters often situated within majestic landscapes. Jane Campion brought her signature style to the small screen in Top of the Lake, using silhouette to dramatically position protagonists within the grandeur of the New Zealand environment.

results.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

key_work.title: My Hometown – Munro Melano
key_work.brief_description: When he was just 17-years old, drummer Leon Isackson started capturing his life on the road from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown ‘ (2014).

end.creator_credit: Kirsten Johnson, Marilyn Ness, Big Mouth Productions, Chicken & Egg Pictures, Fork Films, The Bertha Foundation, Doris Baizley and Lisa Freedman
end.brief_description: As a visually radical memoir, CAMERAPERSON draws on the remarkable footage that filmmaker Kirsten Johnson has shot and reframes it in ways that illuminate moments and situations that have personally affected her. What emerges is an elegant meditation on the relationship between truth and the camera frame, as Johnson transforms scenes that have been presented on Festival screens as one kind of truth into another kind of story—one about personal journey, craft, and direct human connection.

end.title: North by northwest
end.creator_credit: Alfred Hitchcock and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
end.brief_description: Alfred Hitchcock nominated this literal cliff hanger as the film that most epitomised the elements of his years of making thrillers. Roger Thornhill (Cary Grant) is a smug but successful Madison Avenue advertising executive who is plunged into the world of espionage when he his mistaken for mythical agent George Kaplan who US intelligence has created to flush out spies. Matters are further complicated when he meets Eve Kendall (Eva Saint-Marie) who further jeopardises his life while being romantically involved with him. Kidnapped by spies, Thornhill escapes but is then accused of killing a UN diplomat. He is pursued by both spies and the police and desperately flees across country, buzzed by a crop duster plane in one of the films most memorable scenes. His meeting with arch spy James Mason on the Mount Rushmore monument provides the heart-stopping climax as the pair fight it out on the giant sculptures of former US presidents.

Kidnapped by spies, Thornhill escapes but is then accused of killing a UN diplomat. He is pursued by both spies and the police and desperately flees across country, buzzed by a crop duster plane in one of the films most memorable scenes. His meeting with arch spy James Mason on the Mount Rushmore monument provides the heart-stopping climax as the pair fight it out on the giant sculptures of former US presidents.

end.title: Elevator Action
end.brief_description:
Elevator Action (エレベーターアクション Erebētā Akushon) is a 1983 arcade game by Taito. It debuted during the “Golden Age of Arcade Games”. Innovative in gameplay, the game was very popular for many years.

In the game, the player assumes the role of a spy who infiltrates a building filled with elevators. He must collect secret documents from the building and traverse the 30 floors of the building using an increasingly complex series of elevators. The player is pursued by enemy agents who appear from behind closed doors. These agents must be dealt with via force or evasion. Successful completion of a level involves collecting all the secret documents and traversing the building from top to bottom. In the lower floors of the building, the elevator systems are so complex that some puzzle-solving skills are needed.

The game was available as a standard upright cabinet The controls consist of a 4-way joystick and two buttons, one for “shoot” and the other for jumping and kicking. The maximum number of players is two, alternating turns. The graphics are extremely simple, 2D color graphics and in-game music was composed by musician Yoshio Imamura. The game was followed by a sequel, Elevator Action II (also known as Elevator Action Returns).

links.description: While no dialogue is spoken the silence of the elevator scene in Bombshell speaks volumes. Tightly confined, it’s the only time in which Kayla, Megyn and Gretchen, who have all experienced harassment, appear together. While physically close they are emotionally distanced, all feeling powerless.
